key_work.title: Zoetrope and praxinoscope
key_work.brief_description: In 1834, two years after the phenakistoscope was invented in Europe, British mathematician William George Horner created his own version, the zoetrope, which used a cylindrical viewing drum containing a strip of sequenced pictures viewable through thin slits.

links.description: The zoetrope and praxinoscope used sequential pictures to produce the illusion of movement. It was one of the first animation techniques and inspired animation master, Studio’s Ghibli’s Hayao Miyazaki to commission a zoetrope for the studio’s museum using characters from My Neighbour Totoro.
